Michigan State University University Relations Graphic Standards {{color box|#18453b}}{{color box|#ffffff}} |city= [[East Lansing, Michigan]] |country= [[United States|USA]] |mascot= [[Sparty]] |campus= Suburban
(21 km2) campus
10,000 acres (8 km2) in existing or planned development |sports= [[Michigan State Spartans|Spartans]] |website= [http://www.msu.edu/ msu.edu] |logo= [[File:Michigan State University wordmark.svg|230px]] }} '''Michigan State University''' ('''MSU''') is a [[public university|public]] research university in [[East Lansing, Michigan]], USA. Founded in 1855, it was the pioneer [[land-grant institution]] and served as a model for future land-grant colleges in the United States under the 1862 [[Morrill Land-Grant Colleges Act|Morrill Act]]. MSU pioneered the studies of [[packaging]], [[Hospitality management studies|hospitality business]], [[telecommunication]] and [[music therapy]].{{Citation needed (lead)|date=February 2011}} Today its [[study abroad|study-abroad]] program is the largest of any single-campus university in the country, offering more than 200 programs in more than 60 countries on all continents including [[Antarctica]]. It is considered to be one of America's [[Public Ivy]] universities, which recognizes top public research universities in the United States.Greene, Howard and Greene, Matthew. ''The Public Ivies: America's Flagship Public Universities'' (New York: HarperCollins, 2001). ISBN 0-06-093459-X. Following the introduction of the [[Morrill Act]], the college became [[coeducation]]al and expanded its curriculum beyond [[agriculture]]. Today, MSU is the [[List of largest United States university campuses by enrollment|ninth-largest university]] in the United States, with 47,800 students and 2,954 [[Faculty (teaching staff)|faculty]] members. The school's [[nuclear physics]], [[engineering]], [[political science]], [[business]], [[journalism]], [[education]], [[law]] and [[osteopathic medicine]] programs are among the nation's best. MSU's [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] sports teams are called the [[Michigan State Spartans|Spartans]]. They compete in the [[Big Ten Conference]] in all sports except ice hockey, in which the team is part of the [[Central Collegiate Hockey Association]]. MSU's [[American football|football]] [[Michigan State Spartans football|team]] won the [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] in 1954, 1956 and 1988 and boasts six national championships."[http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/msu/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/133-170-spartan-history.pdf]". College Football Data Warehouse. Accessed December 28, 2007. {{Wayback|url=http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/bigten/michigan_state/national_champs.php|date =20070320093240|bot=DASHBot}} Its men's basketball team won the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA National Championship]] in 1979 and 2000 and is currently enjoying a streak of six [[Final Four]] appearances over the last 13 seasons. MSU men's [[ice hockey]] won [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship|national titles]] in 1966, 1986 and 2007. Cross country has historically been Michigan State's most successful sport, especially during a four-decade period spanning roughly 1930â1970 during which the Spartans won eight NCAA championships and numerous other conference and national titles.Frimodig, L., & Stabley, F. (1971). Spartan Saga: A History of Michigan State Athletics. East Lansing: Michigan State University. == History == {{Main|History of Michigan State University}} === Agriculture school === [[Image:Beaumont Tower 10 2007 BR.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Beaumont Tower]] marks the site of [[College Hall (Michigan State University)|College Hall]].]] The [[Michigan Constitution]] of 1850 called for the creation of an "agricultural school","[[s:Michigan Constitution of 1850|Michigan Constitution of 1850]]". Wikisource. Article 13, Section 11. Retrieved March 5, 2008. though it was not until February 12, 1855, that Michigan [[List of Governors of Michigan|Governor]] [[Kinsley S. Bingham]] signed a bill establishing the United States' first agriculture college, the Agricultural College of the State of Michigan."[http://www.msu.edu/unit/msuarhc/articlepg1.htm Milestones of MSU's Sesquicentennial]". MSU University Archives and Historical Collection. Retrieved March 5, 2008. Classes began on May 13, 1857, with three buildings, five faculty members, and 63 male students. The first president, [[Joseph R. Williams]], designed a curriculum that required more scientific study than practically any undergraduate institution of the era. It balanced [[science]], [[liberal arts]], and practical training. The curriculum excluded [[Latin language|Latin]] and [[Greek language|Greek]] studies, since most applicants did not study any classical languages in their rural high schools. However, it did require three hours of daily [[manual labour|manual labor]], which kept costs down for both the students and the College.{{cite book | author=Darling, Birt. | title=City in the Forest; The Story of Lansing | location=New York | publisher=Stratford House | year=1950|page=121 | lccn=50008202}} Despite Williams' innovations and his defense of education for the masses, the State Board of Education saw Williams' curriculum as [[elitism|elitist]]. They forced him to resign in 1859 and reduced the curriculum to a two-year vocational program. === Land Grant pioneer === In 1860, [[Joseph R. Williams]] became acting [[lieutenant governor]]"[http://www.msu.edu/unit/msuarhc/williams.htm Joseph R. Williams Biographical Information]". MSU University Archives and Historical Collection Accessed March 5, 2008. and helped pass the Reorganization Act of 1861. This gave the College a four-year curriculum and the power to grant [[master's degree]]s. Under the act, a newly created body, known as the State Board of Agriculture, took over from the State Board of Education in running the institution. The College changed its name to State Agricultural College, and its first class graduated in the same year. As the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] had just begun, there was no time for an elaborate graduation ceremony. The first alumni enlisted to the [[Union Army]]. The following year, [[Abraham Lincoln]] signed the First [[Morrill Act]] of 1862 to support similar colleges, making the Michigan school a national model. Williams had died the previous year. === Co-ed college === [[Image:Cowles House 10 2007 BR.jpg|thumb|left|The Alice B Cowles House is the official home of the university president and is the oldest existing building on campus.]] The college first admitted women in 1870, although at that time there were no female residence halls. The few women who enrolled either boarded with faculty families or made the arduous [[stagecoach]] trek from Lansing. From the early days, female students took the same rigorous scientific agriculture courses as male students. In 1896, the faculty created a "Women Course" that melded a [[Family and consumer science|home economics]] curriculum with [[liberal arts]] and sciences. That same year, the College turned the old Abbot Hall male dorm into a women's dormitory. It was not until 1899 that the State Agricultural College admitted its first [[African American]] student, William O. Thompson. After graduation, he taught at what is now [[Tuskegee University]]. President Jonathan L. Snyder invited its president [[Booker T. Washington]] to be the Class of 1900 commencement speaker. A few years later, Myrtle Craig became the first woman African-American student to enroll at the College. Along with the Class of 1907, she received her degree from U.S. President [[Theodore Roosevelt]], commencement speaker for the Semi-Centennial celebration. The City of East Lansing was incorporated in that same year,{{cite book | author=Miller, Whitney. | title=East Lansing: Collegeville Revisited (Images of America) | location=Charleston, South Carolina | publisher=Arcadia Publishing | year=2002 | isbn=0-7385-2045-4 | page=26}} and two years later the college officially changed its name to Michigan Agricultural College (M.A.C.). === Big Ten university === During the early 20th century, M.A.C. expanded its curriculum well beyond agriculture. By 1925 it had expanded enough that it changed its name to Michigan State College of Agriculture and Applied Science (M.S.C.). In 1941 the Secretary of the State Board of Agriculture, [[John A. Hannah]], became president of the College. He began the largest expansion in the institution's history, with the help of the 1945 [[G. I. Bill of Rights|G.I. Bill]], which helped World War II veterans to receive an education. One of Hannah's strategies was to build a new dormitory building, enroll enough students to fill it, and use the income to start construction on a new dormitory. Under his plan, enrollment increased from 15,000 in 1950 to 38,000 in 1965.{{cite book | author=Heineman, Kenneth J. | title=Campus Wars: The Peace Movement at American State Universities in the Vietnam Era | location=New York | publisher=New York University Press | year=1993 | isbn=0-8147-3512-6|page=21}} In 1957 Hannah continued MSU's expansion by co-founding Michigan State UniversityâOakland, now [[Oakland University]], with [[Matilda Dodge Wilson]]. Hannah also got the chance to improve the athletic reputation of M.S.C. when the [[University of Chicago]] resigned from the [[Big Ten Conference]] in 1946. Hannah lobbied hard to take its place, gaining admission in 1949.{{cite news|title=It's Big 10 Now â Spartans Admitted|accessdate=2010-06-12|newspaper=Wisconsin State Journal|date=1949-05-21, p. 13}} Six years later, in its Centennial year of 1955, the State of Michigan renamed the College as Michigan State University of Agriculture and Applied Science.{{cite book | author=Kuhn, Madison. | title=Michigan State: The First Hundred Years, 1855â1955 | location=East Lansing | publisher=Michigan State University Press | year=1955 | isbn=0-87013-222-9 | page=471}} Nine years after that, the University governing body changed its name from the State Board of Agriculture to the MSU Board of Trustees. The State of Michigan{{cite web|url=http://www.michigan.gov/ |title=Michigan.gov |publisher=Michigan.gov |date= |accessdate=2010-11-15}} allowed the University to drop the words "Agriculture and Applied Science" from its name. Since 1964 the institution has gone by the name of Michigan State University. === Global leader by 2012 === [[Image:MSU Cyclotron.jpg|thumb|right|The [[National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory]] features one of the most powerful instruments of its type in the world.Bruns, Adam (January 2009).[http://www.siteselection.com/features/2009/jan/Michigan/ How Are You Helping Companies Grow?].''Site Selection Magazine''. Retrieved on December 27, 2009.]] Since the end of the Hannah era, Michigan State has shifted its focus from increasing the size of its student body to advancing its national and global reputation. In September 2005, current president [[Lou Anna Simon]] called for MSU, one of the [[Public Ivy|public ivy institutions]], to become the global model leader for Land Grant institutions by the year 2012. Her plans include creating a new [[residential college]] and increasing grants awarded from the [[National Institutes of Health]] past the [[United States dollar|$]]100 million mark. While there are over 100 [[Land-grant universities]] in the United States, she has stated that she would like Michigan State University to be the leader.Darrow, Bob. [http://www.statenews.com/index.php/article/2005/09/simon_msu_to_be_model Simon: MSU to be model university]. ''The State News''. September 9, 2005. Retrieved March 5, 2008. Michigan State, the [[University of Michigan]] and [[Wayne State University]] created the [[University Research Corridor]] in 2006.{{cite web | title = MSU, U-M, Wayne State create University Research Corridor | publisher = MSU News | url =http://news.msu.edu/story/1317/ | accessdate = July 1, 2011}} This alliance was formed to transform and strength Michigan's economy by reaching out to businesses, policymakers, innovators, investors and the public to speed up technology transfer, make resources more accessible and help attract new jobs to the state. == Campus == {{Main|Campus of Michigan State University}} [[Image:MSU Campus Map small rev3.png|thumb|right|MSU's main campus lies north of the CN Railway and south of Michigan and Grand River Avenues.]] MSU's sprawling campus is located in East Lansing, Michigan. The campus is perched on the banks of the [[Red Cedar River (Michigan)|Red Cedar River]]. Development of the campus started in 1856 with three buildings: a multipurpose building called [[College Hall (Michigan State University)|College Hall]], a dormitory later called "[[Saints' Rest]]",[http://web.archive.org/web/20070613062800/http://www.s150.msu.edu/SaintsRest.php Saints' Rest: Early Campus Life at MSU.] Michigan State University. Retrieved on March 5, 2008. and a barn. Today, MSU's contiguous campus consists of {{convert|5200|acre|km2}}, {{convert|2000|acre|km2}} of which are developed. There are 556 buildings: 100 for academics, 131 for [[agriculture]], 166 for housing and [[food service]], and 42 for athletics. Overall, the university has {{convert|22,763,025|ft2|m2}} of total indoor space."[http://www.eas.msu.edu/fit/reports/buildingdatasummary.cfr Building Data Summary]". ''MSU Physical Plant''. Retrieved February 18, 2010. Connecting it all is {{convert|26|mi|km}} of roads and {{convert|100|mi|km}} of sidewalks."[http://www.rcpd.msu.edu/FAQ Frequently Asked Questions]". MSU Resource Center for Persons with Disabilities (RCPD). Retrieved March 5, 2008. MSU also owns 44 non-campus properties, totaling {{convert|22000|acre|km2}} in 28 different counties."[http://www.canr.msu.edu/lmo/index.htm Land Management Office]". Michigan State University Land Management Office. August 29, 2005. Retrieved March 5, 2008. [[Image:MSU Beaumont Tower 1.jpg|left|thumb|View of Beaumont Tower from the north.]] === North campus === The oldest part of campus lies on the north bank of the Red Cedar.{{cite web|last=Forsyth|first=Kevin S.|title=Michigan Agricultural College â Introduction|url=http://kevinforsyth.net/ELMI/campus.htm|work=A Brief History of East Lansing, Michigan|accessdate=25 February 2011|year=2003}} It includes [[Collegiate Gothic]] architecture, plentiful trees, and curving roads with few straight lines. It was in this area that the College built its first three buildings, of which none survive. Other historic buildings north of the river include [[Cowles House (East Lansing, Michigan)|Cowles House]], the president's official residence, and [[Beaumont Tower]], a [[carillon]] clock tower marking the site of [[College Hall (Michigan State University)|College Hall]], the original classroom building. To the east lies [[EustaceâCole Hall]], America's first freestanding laboratory for [[horticulture]].{{cite book | author=Stanford, Linda O. | title=MSU Campus: Buildings, Places, Spaces | location=East Lansing | publisher=Michigan State University Press | year=2002 | isbn=0-87013-631-3|page=60}} Other landmarks include the bronze statue of former president [[John A. Hannah]],Roeschke, Jaclyn. "[http://www.statenews.com/index.php/article/2004/09/former_039u039_president Former 'U' president immortalized with bronze statue]". ''The State News''. September 20, 2004. Retrieved March 5, 2008. the [[W. J. Beal Botanical Garden]], and the painted boulder known as "[[The Rock (Michigan State University)|The Rock]]", which is a popular spot for theatre, [[tailgate party|tailgating]], and candlelight vigils. On the northwest corner of campus lies the University's hotel, the Kellogg Hotel and Conference Center. The university also has a museum, initiated in 1857. MSU Museum is one of the oldest museums in the Midwest and is accredited by the American Association of Museums."[http://museum.msu.edu/GeneralInformation/About/ MSU Museum â About the Museum]". Retrieved February 25, 2009. === South campus === [[Image:MSU Wharton Center.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Wharton Center for Performing Arts]] hosts many productions throughout the year and was host to the final US Presidential Debate before the 1992 election.]]
The campus south of the river consists mostly of post-World War II [[International Style (architecture)|International Style]] buildings with sparse foliage, relatively straight roadways, and numerous parking lots. The "2020 Vision" Master Plan proposes replacing these parking lots with [[multi-storey car park|parking ramps]] and green space,"[https://prod.gis.msu.edu/construction/update.jsp 2020 Vision Campus Master Plan]". MSU Campus Planning and Administration. 2006. Accessed March 5, 2008. {{Wayback|url=http://www.2020vision.msu.edu/construction/|date =20080315235959|bot=DASHBot}} but these plans will take many years to reach fruition. As part of the master plan, the University erected a new bronze statue of ''[[Sparty|The Spartan]]'' in 2005. This replica replaced the original [[modernist]] [[terra cotta]] statue,{{Cite book|author=Stanford, Linda | title=MSU Campus: Buildings, Places, Spaces | location=East Lansing, Michigan| publisher=Michigan State University Press | year=2002|isbn=0-87013-631-3}} which can still be seen inside [[Spartan Stadium, East Lansing|Spartan Stadium]]. Notable academic and research buildings on the South Campus include the [[National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory|Cyclotron]] and the [[Michigan State University College of Law|College of Law]]. This part of campus is home to the [[Michigan State University Horticulture Gardens|MSU Horticulture Gardens]] and the adjoining [[4-H]] Children's Garden. South of the gardens lie the [[Canadian National]] and [[CSX Transportation|CSX]] railroads, which divide the main campus from thousands of acres of university-owned farmland. The university's agricultural facilities include the Horse, Dairy Cattle, Beef Cattle, Sheep, and Poultry Teaching and Research Farms, as well as the Air Quality Control Lab and the Diagnostics Center for Population and Animal Health. {{-}} === Dubai Education Center === In 2007, Michigan State University established an education center in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. MSU Dubai was the first American university with a presence in [[Dubai International Academic City]], with classes beginning in August 2008. The University offered six undergraduate programs: Business Administration; Child and Youth Development; Construction Project Management; Early Childhood Education; Media Management and Research; Computer Engineering, which later was changed to Electrical and Computer Engineering; and a Master's Degree in Human Resources & Labor Relations. The University attracted over 100 students from all over the Middle East and beyond.About Michigan State University Dubai â http://dubai.msu.edu/quick-facts/about-msu-dubai/news/msu-dubai-challenges-middle-east-students-dream-big-committing-new- During the 2009-2010 academic year MSU Dubai intended to seek licensure through the Commission for Academic Accreditation of the U.A.E. with the goal of full program accreditation prior to the graduation of its first class in 2012.http://dubai.msu.edu/quick-facts/about-msu-dubai After two years of activity, MSU shut down all undergraduate programs in Dubai due to financial reasons. The Dubai campus remains as a research site, a Study Abroad center, and for its dozen graduate students. === Kellogg Hotel and Conference Center === The Kellogg Hotel and Conference Center doubles as a 4-star hotel and a business friendly conference center. It is located on the northwest corner of Michigan State Universityâs campus, across from the [[Brody Complex]], on Harrison Road just south of Michigan Avenue. The hotel has 160 rooms and suites which can accommodate anyone staying in East Lansing for a business conference, sporting event or an on-campus visit, but it originally served as a dormitory for MSU students. Besides a lodging facility, the Kellogg Hotel and Conference Center serves as a âlearning laboratory for the 300-400 students each year that are enrolled in The School of Hospitality Business and other majors.â The Kellogg Hotel and Conference Center strives to facilitate education by hosting conferences and seminars.{{cite web |url=http://www.kelloggcenter.com/about/history.html |title=Kellogg Hotel and Conference Center |accessdate=May 2, 2011}} == Academics == {{Main|Michigan State University academics}} {{See also|Michigan State University Libraries}} [[Image:MSU Library 1.jpg|thumb|ã£left|[[Michigan State University Libraries|The MSU Library]] is located on the oldest part of campus between [[Beaumont Tower]] and the river.]] MSU has the [[List of largest US universities by enrollment|ninth largest]] student body in the U.S. For the fiscal year of 2009â10, the Office of the Registrar conferred 11,140 degrees.[http://www.reg.msu.edu/ReportServer/Pages/ReportViewer.aspx?/ROReports/UFY-DegreesConf&term_seq_id=1096 Degrees Conferred-Fiscal Year]''Office of the Registar'.' Retrieved June, 22,2010. The student body is 55% female and 45% male. While 89% of students come from all 83 counties in the State of Michigan,"Michigan State University: Student Body". ''The Princeton Review''. 2005. also represented are all 50 states in the U.S. and about 130 other countries. In 2010-2011 5,351 international students enrolled at MSU. The top five countries represented: China, Korea, India, Taiwan and Canada. [http://oiss.isp.msu.edu/about_stats.php] MSU has about 4,500 faculty and 6,000 staff members, and a student/faculty ratio of 19:1.{{cite book | author=Davis, Amy. | title=Michigan State University Off the Record | publisher=College Prowler | year=2005 | isbn=1-59658-083-6 | page=4}} Listed as a [[Public Ivy]],{{cite book | author=Greene, Howard R. & Greene, Matthew W. | year=2001 | title=The Public Ivies: Americaâs Flagship Public Universities (1st ed.) | publisher=New York: Cliff Street Books | isbn=0-06-093459-X}} Michigan State is a member of the [[Association of American Universities]]. Michigan State University [[Ombudsman]] is the longest continually operating ombudsman office at a college or university in the country."[http://newsroom.msu.edu/site/indexer/3180/content.htm Americaâs longest-operating Office of the Ombudsman turns 40]". Michigan State University Newsroom. September 19, 2007. Retrieved December 15, 2007. [[Albert Fert]], an [[Adjunct professor]] at MSU, was awarded the 2007 [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] together with [[Peter GrÃ¼nberg]].Thoel, Tara. "[http://statenews.com/index.php/article/2007/10/adjunct_physics_professor_at_msu_wins_nobel_prize Adjunct physics professor at MSU wins Nobel Prize]". ''The State News''. October 9, 2007. Retrieved December 15, 2007. MSU's [[study abroad]] program is the largest of any single-campus university in the United States with 2,461 students studying abroad in 2004â2005 in over 60 countries on all continents, including [[Antarctica]]."[http://studyabroad.msu.edu/programs/antarcticscience.html Studies in Antarctic System ScienceâAntarctica]". MSU Office of Study Abroad. Retrieved March 5, 2008. MSU has six faculty members elected to the National Academy of Sciences (NAS); Martin Bukovac (1983), James Dye (1989), Pamela Fraker (2007), Richard Lenski (2006), Michael Thomashow (2003), and James Tiedje (2003).[http://www.nasonline.org/site/Dir/605305206?pg=rslts Search] ''National Academy of Sciences'.' Retrieved April 8, 2010. Its admissions are moderately difficult; for 2009's entering class, the 25th/75th percentiles for the SAT were 1030 and 1240/1600, and its 25th/75th percentiles on the ACT were 23 and 27/36.[http://trustees.msu.edu/meetings/pdfs/bot_minutes_9_11_2009.pdf] ''MSU Board of Trustee Minutes'.' Retrieved October 24, 2010. === Rankings === {{Infobox US university ranking | QS_W = 164 | GUR = 36â39 | ARWU_W = 92 | ARWU_N = 50 | ARWU_SOC = 32 | ARWU_BUS = 34 | CMUP = 43 | USNWR_NU =71 | USNWR_Bus = 46 | USNWR_Medc = 7 | USNWR_Eng = 58 | USNWR_Ed = 17 | Wamo_NU = 33 | Forbes = 282 | THES_W = 96 | FSPI = 86 }} Michigan State ranks {{ordinal|92}} in the world, according to a [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University]] study, which measures scientific research leading towards a [[Nobel Prize]]."[http://www.shanghairanking.com/ARWU2011.html Top 500 World Universities]". Retrieved November 03, 2011. ''U.S. News and World Report''. Retrieved February 22, 2008. programs No.1 for the last 14 years. The National Communication Association (NCA) ranks MSUâs Ph.D. programs as No. 1 in educating researchers in the rapidly growing fields of health communication and communication technology. MSU is also ranked number four in several other fields, including international/intercultural communication, mass communication, and interpersonal communication based on the November 2004 NCA report. "[http://www.natcom.org/Default.aspx?id=630&libID=651 NCA Doctoral Reputational Study, 2004]''National Communication Association''. Retrieved November 29, 2010. The Eli Broad College of Business was ranked No. 9 among public institutions and No. 20 nationally in 2010 by ''Business Week''.{{cite web|title=The Best U.S. B-Schools of 2010|url=http://www.businessweek.com/interactive_reports/bs_2010_US_FTMBA_TAB_1111.html|work=Business Week|accessdate=3 December 2010|date=11 November 2010}} The 2008 ''U.S. News'' ranked Michigan State's [[Supply Chain Management]] program in the Eli Broad College of Business No.1 in the nation for the second year in a row."[http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/college/rankings/brief/bizspec10_brief.php Supply Chain Management/Logistics]". ''USNews.com:America's Best Colleges 2008''. Retrieved March 5, 2008. In addition, the Eli Broad College of Business undergraduate accounting program is ranked 11th overall and 8th among public schools, the graduate accounting program is ranked 9th overall and 6th among public schools, and the doctoral program is ranked 8th overall and 5th among public schools according to the 2010 ''[[Public Accounting Report]]'''s Annual Survey of Accounting Professors. {{cite web | title = Annual PAR ranks all Broad accounting programs in top 10 among publics | publisher = Eli Broad College of Business | url =http://broad.msu.edu/information/news/item?oid=1923 | accessdate = July 1, 2011}} The College of Communication Arts and Sciences was established in 1955 and was the first of its kind in the United States.{{cite web | title = Distinctions for College of Communication Arts and Sciences | publisher = Michigan State University | url =http://msu.edu/about/rankings-and-recognitions/distinctions/communication-arts-and-sciences.html | accessdate = July 1, 2011}} The college's Media and Information Studies doctoral program was ranked No. 2 in 2007 by ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]'' in the category of mass communication. The communication doctoral program was ranked No. 4 in a separate category of communication in ''The Chronicle of Higher Education'''s 2005 Faculty Scholarly Productivity Index, published in 2007. The college's faculty and alumni include eight [[Pulitzer Prize]] winners and a two-time [[Emmy Award]] winning recording mixer. MSUâs graduate program in [[nuclear physics]] is ranked No. 1 in the nation by U.S. News. In [[primary care|primary medical care]], ''U.S. News'' ranks MSU's College of Osteopathic Medicine at No.5, College of [[Veterinary Medicine]] at No.9, and the College of Human Medicine at No.18."[http://newsroom.msu.edu/site/indexer/3044/content.htm MSU professional and grad programs maintain strong positions in rankings]". Michigan State University Newsroom. March 30, 2007. Retrieved March 6, 2008. Other programs of note include [[criminal justice]],Rykert, Wilbur Lewis. "The History of the School of Criminal Justice at Michigan State University 1935â1963" (Masters Thesis). 1985. [[music therapy]],"[http://www.music.msu.edu/about/fastfacts.php About Us: Fast Facts]". MSU College of Music. December 10, 2004. Retrieved January 30, 2008. The Sustainable Endowments Institute awarded Michigan State with an overall grade of "B" on the 2009 Campus Sustainability Survey, including "A"s in the categories of Administration, Transportation, Endowment Transparency, and Investment Policies.{{cite web|url=http://greenreportcard.org/report-card-2009/schools/michigan-state-university |title=Greenreportcard.org |publisher=Greenreportcard.org |date=2008-06-30 |accessdate=2010-11-15}} === Research === [[Image:MSU Computer Center.jpg|thumb|The Computer Center once housed the early research computer [[MISTIC]]]] The university spent nearly [[United States dollar|$]]405 million in 2008â09 on research, capping a long history of academic research. In 1877, botany professor [[William J. Beal]] performed the first documented genetic crosses to produce hybrid [[maize|corn]], which led to increased yields. MSU dairy professor [[G. Malcolm Trout]] invented the process for the [[Homogenization (chemistry)|homogenization]] of milk in the 1930s. In the 1960s, MSU scientists developed [[cisplatin]], a leading cancer fighting drug.
Today Michigan State continues its research with facilities such as the [[United States Department of Energy|U.S. Department of Energy]]-sponsored MSU-DOE Plant Research Laboratory{{cite web|url=http://prl.msu.edu/ |title=Michigan State University | College of Natural Science | Plant Research Laboratory |publisher=Prl.msu.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-11-15}} and a [[particle accelerator]] called the [[National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory]]. The U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science named Michigan State University as the site for the [[Facility for Rare Isotope Beams]] (FRIB). The $550 million facility will attract top researchers from around the world to conduct experiments in basic nuclear science, astrophysics, and applications of isotopes to other fields. [[Image:MSU Vet Research Farm.jpg|thumb|right|The Veterinary Research Farm.]] In 2004, scientists at the Cyclotron produced and observed a new isotope of the element [[germanium]], called Ge-60"[http://www.nscl.msu.edu/science/nuggets/60Ge First observation of Germanium-60 and Selenium-64]". ''NSCL Science Nuggets''. Retrieved April 10, 2010. In that same year, Michigan State, in consortium with the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] and the government of [[Brazil]], broke ground on the 4.1-meter [[SOAR Telescope|Southern Astrophysical Research Telescope]] (SOAR) in the [[Andes Mountains]] of [[Chile]]. The consortium telescope will allow the Physics & Astronomy department to study galaxy formation and origins."[http://www.msu.edu/thisismsu/points_pride.html Points of Pride]". ''MSU Today''. Accessed March 5, 2008. {{Wayback|url=http://www.msu.edu/thisismsu/points_pride.html|date =20080315235959|bot=DASHBot}} Since 1999, MSU has been part of another consortium called the [[Michigan Life Sciences Corridor]], which aims to develop [[biotechnology]] research in the State of Michigan.Truscott, John. "[http://www.state.mi.us/migov/gov/PressReleases/199907/LifeSciencesCorridorPR.htm Governor Signs Bill Creating 'Life Sciences Corridor' in Michigan]". Michigan Executive Office press release. July 19, 1999. Retrieved March 5, 2008. Finally, the College of Communication Arts and Sciences' [[Quello Center for Telecommunication Management and Law|Quello Center]] researches current issues of information and communication management. === Endowment === MSU's (private, non-Morrill Act) [[financial endowment|endowment]] started in 1916 when the Engineering Building burned down. Automobile magnate [[R.E. Olds]] helped the program stay afloat with a gift of $100,000.{{cite book | author=Rodriguez, Michael | title=R.E. Olds and Industrial Lansing | location=Charleston, South Carolina | publisher=Arcadia Publishing | year=2004 | isbn=0-7385-3272-X | page=117}} There was a time when MSU lagged behind peer institutions in terms of endowments. As recently as the early 1990s, MSU was last among the eleven Big Ten schools, with barely over $100 million in endowment funds. That changed dramatically in the first decade of the 21st century, when the University started a campaign to increase the size of the endowment. At the close of [[fiscal year]] 2004â2005, the endowment had risen to $1.325 billion, raising the University to sixth of the 11 Big Ten schools in terms of endowment; within $2 million of the fifth-rated school.Seguin, Rick. "[http://newsbulletin.msu.edu/jan2606/endowment.html Endowment surges in growth, rankings]". MSU News Bulletin. 2006. Retrieved March 5, 2008. The rapid increase in the size of the endowment will help to improve outdated facilities, such as the Music Building, which the College of Music hopes to soon replace with money from its alumni fundraising program."[http://www.music.msu.edu/alumni/campaign.php Capital Campaign]". MSU School of Music. Accessed March 5, 2008. {{Wayback|url=http://www.music.msu.edu/alumni/campaign.php|date =20080315235959|bot=DASHBot}} == Colleges == [[Image:MSU South Campus skyline.jpg|thumb|The South Campus skyline]] MSU has over 200 academic programs offered by 17 degree granting colleges. === Residential colleges === MSU has several [[residential colleges]], based on the [[Oxbridge]] "living-learning" model. By putting classes in student dormitories, these colleges improve student access to faculty and facilities. MSU's first residential college, [[Justin Morrill]] College started in 1965 with an interdisciplinary curriculum."[http://www.enolagaia.com/JMC.html Unofficial website]". Justin Morrill College. Retrieved March 5, 2008. MSU closed Morrill College in 1979, but today the university has three residential colleges, including the recent opening of the [[Residential College in Arts & Humanities]] (RCAH) located in Snyder and Phillips halls. Established in 1967, [[James Madison College]] is a smaller component residential college in [[political science]] housed in Case Hall. Classes in the college are small, with an average of 25 students, and most instructors are [[tenure]] track faculty. James Madison College has about 1150 students total, with each [[freshman]] class containing about 320 students.[http://web.archive.org/web/20070627063337/http://www.jmc.msu.edu/quickfacts.asp "Quick Madison Facts"]. James Madison College @ Michigan State University. Retrieved June 25, 2007. Each of Madison's four [[Academic major|majors]]âSocial Relations and Policy, International Relations, Political Theory and Constitutional Democracy, and Comparative Cultures and Politics[http://web.archive.org/web/20070814085350/http://www.jmc.msu.edu/ps/youandjmc.asp "You and JMC"]. James Madison College @ Michigan State University. Retrieved June 25, 2007.ârequires two years of foreign language and one semester of "field experienceâ in an [[intern]]ship or study abroad program. Although Madison students make up about 4% of MSU graduates, they represent around 35% of the MSUâs [[Phi Beta Kappa Society|Phi Beta Kappa]] members."[http://web.archive.org/web/20071020201533/http://jmc.msu.edu/quickfacts.asp Quick Madison Facts]". James Madison College @ Michigan State University. Retrieved March 5, 2008. [[Image:MSU Phillips Hall.jpg|thumb|right|Snyder-Phillips Hall was built in 1947. The building was recently expanded to make room for a new residential college.]] Also established in 1967, [[Lyman Briggs College]] teaches math and science within social, historical and philosophical contexts."[http://www.lymanbriggs.msu.edu/future/educationalPhilosophy.cfm Educational Philosophy]". Lyman Briggs College. Retrieved March 5, 2008. Many Lyman Briggs students intend to pursue careers in medicine, but the school supports over 30 coordinate majors, from human biology to computer sciences."[http://www.lymanbriggs.msu.edu/current/majors.cfm Majors]". Lyman Briggs College. Retrieved June 18, 2010. Lyman Briggs is one of the few colleges that lets undergraduates teach as "Learning Assistants.""[http://www.lymanbriggs.msu.edu/academics/Forms/LAApplication2008-09.pdf Undergraduate Learning Assistant Application 2008â2009]" (PDF). Lyman Briggs College. Accessed March 5, 2008. {{Wayback|url=http://lymanbriggs.msu.edu/current/forms/LA_Application_2010-11.pdf|date =20080410055103|bot=DASHBot}} MSU's newest residential college is the [[Residential College in Arts & Humanities]]. Founded October 21, 2005,Collins, Laura. "[http://www.statenews.com/index.php/article/2005/10/trustees_approve_residential Trustees approve residential college]". ''The State News''. October 24, 2005. Retrieved March 5, 2008. the college provides around 600 [[undergraduates]] with an individualized [[curriculum]] in the [[liberal arts|liberal]], [[visual arts|visual]] and [[performing arts]]. Though all the students will graduate with the same [[academic degree|degree]], MSU encourages students in the college to get a [[Double degree|second degree]] or specialization."[http://rcah.msu.edu/about/program.php How the Program Works]". Michigan State University Residential College in Arts & Humanities. Retrieved December 15, 2007. The university houses the new college in a newly renovated Snyder-Phillips Hall, the location of MSU's first residential college, Justin Morrill College."[http://rcah.msu.edu/living/ Living in the College]". Michigan State University Residential College in Arts & Humanities. Retrieved March 5, 2008. [[Image:MSU Law School 1.jpg|thumb|The MSU Law School Building]] === Professional schools === The [[Michigan State University College of Law]] is an independent, non-profit corporation[http://www.law.msu.edu/faculty_staff/board.html MSU College of Law Board of Trustees] affiliated[http://www.law.msu.edu/news/2005/ten-year-affiliation.html MSU Law News, "Law College to Mark 10-Year Affiliation with MSU", October 17, 2005] with the [[public university|public]] institution. Founded in Detroit in 1891 as the Detroit College of Law, the law school moved to East Lansing in 1995 becoming an integral part of the university. Students attending MSU College of Law come from 42 states and 13 countries. The law school publishes the Michigan State Law Review,"[http://msulr.law.msu.edu/ Main Page]". ''Michigan State Law Review''. Accessed March 5, 2008. {{Wayback|url=http://msulr.law.msu.edu|date =20070702025546|bot=DASHBot}} the Michigan State Journal of International Law and the Journal of Medicine and Law. The College of Law is the home of the [[Geoffrey Fieger]] Trial Practice Institute,"[http://www.law.msu.edu/tpi/ The Geoffrey Fieger Trial Practice Institute]". Michigan State University College of Law. Retrieved March 5, 2008. the first trial practice institute in the United States. The [[Intellectual Property]] and Communications Law program was ranked seventeenth nationally, in 2006.White, Russ. "[http://newsroom.msu.edu/site/indexer/2726/content.htm Press Release]". Michigan State University Newsroom. April 4, 2006. Retrieved March 5, 2008. The [[Eli Broad College of Business]] has programs in [[accounting]], [[information systems]], [[finance]], [[management]], [[marketing]] and [[supply chain management]], and [[The School of Hospitality Business|hospitality business]]. The school has 4,775 [[undergraduate]] students and 776 [[graduate students]]. The Eli Broad Graduate School of Management, which ''[[Business Week]]'' magazine ranks 11th among public institutions, offers three [[MBA]] programs, as well as [[double major|joint degrees]] with the [[Michigan State University College of Law|College of Law]]."[http://www.bus.msu.edu/graduate Graduate Programs]". The Eli Broad College of Business and Eli Broad Graduate School of Management. Retrieved March 6, 2008. The opening of the [[Eugene C. Eppley Center for Graduate Studies in Hotel, Restaurant and Institutional Management]] brought the first program in the United States to offer a Master of Business Administration degree in Hotel, Restaurant and Institutional Management to MSU.[https://www.bus.msu.edu/shb/documents/Historic%20Milestones.pdf "Historic milestones"], MSU School of Hospitality and Business. p 2. Retrieved 6/10/08. The [[Michigan State University College of Nursing]] grants [[Bachelor of Science in Nursing|B.S.N.]], [[Master of Science in Nursing|M.S.N.]], and [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] degrees. === Medical schools === [[File:Msu-chm-secchia-center-evening.jpg|thumb|right|MSU Secchia Center]] The [[MSU College of Osteopathic Medicine]] was the world's first publicly funded college of [[Osteopathic medicine in the United States|osteopathic medicine]]."[http://www.com.msu.edu/osteomed/welcome.html A Message from the Dean]". MSU College of Osteopathic Medicine. Retrieved March 6, 2008. It has a long-standing tradition of retaining its alumni in Michigan to practice â more than two-thirds of the collegeâs graduates remain to practice in Michigan."[http://www.com.msu.edu/osteomed/history.html Brief History of the Michigan State University College of Osteopathic Medicine]". MSU College of Osteopathic Medicine. Retrieved March 6, 2008. Recently, the Michigan State University Board of Trustees approved a resolution endorsing the expansion of the College of Osteopathic Medicine to two sites in [[southeast Michigan]], a move board members and college officials say will not only improve medical education in the state, but also address a projected physician [[shortage]]."[http://www.com.msu.edu/pub-rel/expansion_may2007.html MSU board endorses expansion of osteopathic college to southeast Michigan]". MSU College of Osteopathic Medicine. May 18, 2007. Retrieved March 6, 2008.
According to U.S. News & World Report, the College of Osteopathic Medicine (DO degree) ranked No.8 medical schools in the country for primary care and the College of Human Medicine (MD degree) has regularly ranked among the top thirty medical schools in the country for primary care."[http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/usnews/edu/grad/rankings/med/brief/mdprank_brief.php America's Best Graduate Schools 2008]." ''U.S. News & World Report''. Retrieved March 6, 2008. The [[Michigan State University College of Human Medicine|College of Human Medicine]] graduates students with medical doctor [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] degrees and is split into seven distinct campuses located in [[Lansing]], [[Kalamazoo, Michigan|Kalamazoo]], [[Flint, Michigan|Flint]], [[Saginaw]], [[Marquette, Michigan|Marquette]], [[Traverse City, Michigan|Traverse City]] and [[Grand Rapids]]. Each campus is affiliated with local hospitals and other medical facilities professionals in the area."[http://humanmedicine.msu.edu/future/meded.php/ Medical Education]". Michigan State University College of Human Medicine. Accessed Jun 18, 2010. For example, the Lansing campus includes [[Sparrow Hospital]] and [[Ingham Regional Medical Center]]."[http://humanmedicine.msu.edu/future/meded_lansing.php Lansing Campus]". Michigan State University College of Human Medicine. Retrieved June, 18, 2010. The College of Human Medicine has recently gained attention for its expansion into the Grand Rapids area, with the new [http://www.secchiacenter.com/ Secchia Center] completed in the Fall of 2010, that is expected to fuel the growing medical industry in that region.Schneider, Keith. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/11/realestate/commercial/11hill.html?ex=1187496000&en=07ec444174548dce&ei=50700 Grand Rapids Lays Foundations for a Health Mecca]". ''The New York Times''. July 11, 2007. Retrieved December 10, 2007. Though Michigan State has offered courses in veterinary science since its founding, the [[Michigan State University College of Veterinary Medicine|College of Veterinary Medicine]] was not formally established as a four-year, degree-granting program until 1910."[http://cvm.msu.edu/about-the-college About the College]". Michigan State University College of Veterinary Medicine. Retrieved March 6, 2008. Ranked ninth in the nation, the college has over {{convert|170000|ft2|m2}} of office, teaching, and research space, as well as a veterinary [[teaching hospital]]."[http://cvm.msu.edu/about-the-college/cvm-facilities Facilities]". Michigan State University College of Veterinary Medicine. Retrieved March 6, 2008. === Other academic units === In recent years, MSU's music program has grown substantially. Music major enrollment increased more than 97% between 1991 and 2004."[http://www.music.msu.edu/about/fastfacts.php Fast Facts]". Michigan State University College of Music. Accessed December 15, 2007. {{Wayback|url=http://www.music.msu.edu/about/fastfacts.php|date =20070815153555|bot=DASHBot}} In early 2007, this growth led the university board of trustees to spin the music program off into its own college unit: The MSU College of Music.Harbison, Sarah. "[http://www.statenews.com/index.php/article/2007/02/online_update_music_school Music school becomes MSU's 16th college]". ''The State News''. February 23, 2007. Retrieved March 6, 2008. The new college faces many new challenges, such as working with limited spaceThoel, Tara. "[http://www.statenews.com/index.php/article/2007/10/music_building_overcrowded Music Building overcrowded, students fight for practice time]". ''The State News''. October 16, 2007.
